Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2018 Computational Modeling in Biology Network (COMBINE) Forum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Standards for data exchange are critical to the development of any field. They enable researchers and practitioners to exchange information reliably, apply a variety of tools to their problems, and reproduce scientific results. The COmputational MOdeling in Biology NEtwork (COMBINE) was created in 2010 to organize standardization efforts for systems biology. This effort includes, among others, the systems biology markup language (SBML) for mathematical models created by systems biologists; and the synthetic biology open language (SBOL) for describing genetic designs created by synthetic biologists. While systems biology and synthetic biology have many unique requirements, there are also a lot of overlapping features such as the need to construct mathematical models, describe pathways, and provide visual representations. The COMBINE meetings bring together representatives from both fields to enable these communities to share existing standards, software, and other infrastructure. This project will help enable US-based students from these two communities, particularly those new to these efforts or from underrepresented groups, to meet together at the 2018 COMBINE Forum to be held at Boston University in Boston, Massachusetts on October 8th to 12th (http://co.mbine.org/events/COMBINE_2018).

Workshops like this one are instrumental in making progress in the development of these standards. Currently, most standardization efforts are either unfunded or only have very limited support. Indeed, the success of these standards has been due to the donation of time from many individuals to participate in discussions, write specifications, serve as standard editors, and attend workshops. Many of these individuals working on the development of these standards are students based in the US who would otherwise find it difficult to find the funds to attend this meeting. Therefore, this project would help support travel expenses for these US-based students working on these standards to travel to Boston for COMBINE 2018. Not only would this be a valuable experience for these students, but it would also greatly enhance the synthetic biology community's goal of bringing together researchers in synthetic biology with those working in systems biology leading to integrated standards and shared software and infrastructure. The goals of this workshop will be to continue to (1) develop synergistic relationships between systems and synthetic biology researchers; (2) provide a tighter integration of standard development for systems and synthetic biology; (3) perform outreach to modelers and experimentalists; and (4) discuss a coordinated effort to advocate the use of standards in publications and archival databases to enhance reproducibility of scientific results.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With additional support from residual funds from NSF travel award (#1833474), this project provided partial travel support for 12 students (3 female and 3 more from other underrepresented groups) to attend COMBINE Forum 2018 in Boston Massachusetts. This event is organized annually by the Computational Modeling in Biology Network (COMBINE).  The goal of this event is to promote the development of the standards and supporting infrastructure for systems and synthetic biology, as well as, interoperability between these standards.  The primary COMBINE standards are the systems biology markup language (SBML), systems biology graphical notation (SBGN), simulation experiment description markup language (SED-ML), the biological pathway (BioPAX) description language, the cell markup language (CellML), the neurological modeling language (NeuroML), and the synthetic biology open language (SBOL). 


The COMBINE Forum has a combination of invited talks, contributed talks, and breakout sessions.  All supported students gave either an oral or poster presentation.  During the breakout sessions at the COMBINE Forum, the students were able to participate in the discussions related to the next versions of the COMBINE standards and related efforts.  For example, the students contributed to discussions on, among other things, four specifications that were finalized: SBOL Version 2.3.0, SBGN PD L1V2, SBML L3V2R2, and SBOLv 2.1. These were all published in a special issue of the Journal of Integrative Bioinformatics, Volume 16, Issue 2 (Jun 2019).  This grant was instrumental in these outcomes.  Without this grant, it would have been prohibitively expensive for them to attend.
